message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has schizophrenia and has previously been prescribed risperidone, which indicates that it was an effective medication for him. Since he has been unable to comply with his medications due to his unstable living situation, intramuscular risperidone can be given as a long-term solution. Propranolol and diazepam are not typically used for schizophrenia, and oral haloperidol may not be the best option if the patient has difficulty complying with daily oral medications.

Intravenous propranolol is not used to treat schizophrenia, and oral haloperidol and oral diazepam may not be effective enough for long-term management. Intramuscular risperidone can be useful for patients who have difficulty complying with their medications.

Since the patient has been unable to comply with oral medications, intramuscular risperidone may be a better option for long-term pharmacotherapy. Propranolol is a beta-blocker and is not indicated for treating psychosis. Diazepam is a benzodiazepine and may be useful for anxiety or agitation, but not for treating psychosis. Haloperidol is also an antipsychotic medication, but its use may be limited in this patient due to the risk of extrapyramidal symptoms.
